Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A Systematic Approach, Language and Platform for Building and Distributing Interactive Educational Games in Operations Management
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR phase I project will create a web-based platform for developing and distributing interactive, mobile-enabled games for Information and Operations Management. Each of these games will illustrate one to two fundamental academic concepts by having students engage in short, round-based interactions that last less than one classroom session. Recent studies (Burke, 2012; Sitzmann, 2011), show that educational games, which focus on key concepts and provide immediate feedback to players, help students understand, learn and internalize fundamental academic concepts. The project addresses widespread obstacles reported by professors to incorporate games into their teaching, including the scarcity of games that were both relevant and technically capable in classroom environments. The broader impact of the proposed project is an increase in the adoption of pedagogically and academically validated educational games that facilitate retention and effective use of business concepts relevant to managing organizations. Hence, this proposal has potential to empower the workforce to be more productive and innovative, thus driving U.S. economic growth. Moreover, the eventual opening of the platform to a variety of third-party authors will accelerate game innovation and usage in other business and engineering disciplines at a lower cost, which will enhance the effectiveness of a broader STEM workforce.


This project will employ automatically validated language to eliminate runtime errors in multiplayer Operations Management games, which will have been designed using a scientific Game Research & Development (GR&D) process for hosting on a web-distribution platform. Debugging runtime errors presents a particular challenge for non-professional programmers, such as professors. With runtime errors mitigated, the correctness of a program can be validated at compile time. Therefore, all games created with the project Game Description Language (GDL) will have a guaranteed level of technical quality and stability, allowing professors to focus on pedagogical relevance rather than technical stability of games. To mitigate the problem of runtime errors, this project employs methods of mainstream video game development, which relies heavily on non-professional programmers for storyline scripting. The main technical hurdle is that these methods must be tailored to result in automatically validated language capable of expressing the range of Operations Management games conceived during the GR&D process. The goal of the proposed R&D is a platform prototype able to support 10 simultaneous users of four games implemented using the GDL. Pilot tests with users will assess critical usability metrics to facilitate further, larger-scale testing and GDL improvements in Phase II.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit of this project validated the feasibility to design games in a consistent and rigorous manner through a Game Research and Development (GR&D) process, build the games using automatically validated, domain-specific Game Design Language (GDL) to ensure technical quality and release them for use via a Game Distribution Platform (GDP) to simplify management and gameplay in the classroom. The outcome of the project was the release of three games – the Distribution Game, the Forecast Sharing Game and the Newsvendor Game – on the Fathomd platform for limited classroom use.

 

The project also achieved broader impacts (1) in multiple academic disciplines (e.g., Operations Management); (2) in the development of human resources; (3) in educational infrastructure supporting higher education; (4) in technology advancements; and (5) more broadly for modern society. First, the Fathomd platform has demonstrated the feasibility to increase the availability of pedagogically validated educational games covering all major topic areas of Operations Management courses. Through the release of our first games, we expect to increase adoption of game-based learning, which still suffers from significant challenges to incorporating into class teaching. Our technology will serve as a platform to more rapidly and effectively create varied game types for use in multiple disciplines. Once we open this technology to authors of other STEM subjects we believe we will be able to encourage more widespread use of games to teach these subjects as well, which should improve overall learning outcomes for students in STEM.

 

Second, Fathomd games allow real-time results and feedback during the class, which enable a professor to customize the learning experience; the professor observes the level of understanding among students, tailors the discussion to address particular topics and engages the class to reach specific learning objectives. The outcome is that students more effectively understand and retain concepts while professors gain an instructional tool that requires a minimal technical effort to facilitate an effective game experience. Managers in organizations will also benefit from such game-based learning because many corporate training and development programs are based on university business programs and are taught by professors. As evidence of this application, Fathomd has received interest from leading global organizations such as Uber to utilize games in the training of employees.

Third, our technology is completely cloud-based, works in any modern browser, and the GDL is an automatically validated, domain-specific language that accelerates game development while ensuring technical stability. In our model, the cost of development other than time to the author is effectively zero, while the cost of access is simply the cost per game. As a result, there should be less and less need for expensive computing devices, large laboratories, and expensive physical spaces in schools. Users can simply rely on generally available technologies (e.g., phones, laptops) to use games in education.  Moreover, our games support the proliferation of online course platforms (e.g., Coursera) because the games can be played online from any location. These products could drastically increase the availability of education programs worldwide, especially providing access to students in disadvantaged economic areas or to students without the capability to attend full time programs.  In summary, the benefits of game-based programs will become the foundation for next-generation education channels for students.

 

Fourth, at the commercial level, we expect our technology innovations to change how educational game development is performed as an industry. The GR&D, GDL and GDP will offer unique capability to promote growth and meritocracy in the process of developing and distributing educational games. For example, the feature set of our GDP may also prove to set a “gold standard” for how game setup and management should be accomplished. In the long-term we hope to drive consolidation in the educational game industry, which will further promote expansion of game-based learning.

 

Finally, start-ups, for-profit and nonprofit companies all need managers who can make effective decisions in the face of complexity and uncertainty. It is of the utmost importance to society, therefore, that the next generation of business leaders is equipped with relevant frameworks and tools that supplement traditional teaching methods and enable effective use of knowledge on the job.  Conceivably, this research will help us to improve education outcomes; by increasing the availability and usability of classroom-ready games, Fathomd seeks to empower future business leaders in the global economy to make better decisions while leading companies. Hence, this project has the potential to empower the workforce to be more productive and innovative, thus driving U.S. economic growth.
